heading: virgin to burn net music cds
subheading: virgin megastores launch a kiosk service to let customers walk out of the store with a cd full of internet music. by chris oakes.
author: chris oakes
text: virgin megastore customers will be checking out internet music along with the rest of their cds this fall. virgin entertainment group launched a new kiosk service thursday that will allow in-store customers to burn internet music onto cds for purchase."integrating music found only online into our retail stores goes far in furthering our mission as a leading advocate for consumers and artists," said russ pillar, virgin entertainment group's president and chief executive officer, in a statement.read wired news' ongoing mp3 coveragebrowse webmonkey's mp3 guide- - - - - -customers can download selected tracks from eight popular internet music sites, and for us$10 walk out with a cd containing 10 tracks of their choosing.virgin is launching the new system at the opening of its columbus, ohio megastore 16 july. the plan calls for installing the system in the rest of virgin's megastores this fall.customers will pick from about 100 tracks found on eight different internet music sites that have entered an agreement with network and kiosk service, reddotnet.thursday's announcement is the first installment of the system. the network has reached agreements with liquid audio's liquid music network, cductive, amp3.com, amplified.com, songs.com, riffage.com, mjuice, and noisebox.before burning a customer cd, kiosk users can preview and pick from approximately 800 tracks selected as the site's best music.customers will use the red dot network and kiosk to download full albums from major record labels starting this fall, the company said.
